Award.AwardTitle: Submanifolds and Metrics in Contact Geometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
Contact structures on manifolds are natural objects, born over two centuries ago, in the work of Huygens, Hamilton, and Jacobi, on geometric optics. They have been studied by many mathematicians and seem to touch on diverse areas of mathematics and physics, but only in the last few decades have they moved into the foreground of mathematics. This is due to the remarkable breakthroughs in contact topology, resulting in a rich and beautiful theory with many applications. Studying subsets and their interactions with such structures was instrumental in the understanding of three-dimensional spaces, and it led to profound progress. The Principal Investigator will now extend this to higher dimensions, where this exploration is likely to prove equally illuminating. The Principal Investigator will also continue to study properties of contact structures on low-dimensional spaces and their interaction with topology and Riemannian geometry, and he will train the next generation of researchers by working with a large group of graduate students and organizing conferences and seminars.

The research supported by this award will focus on problems centered around three broad topics: the interactions of contact geometry and topology in low dimensions, properties and constructions of contact manifolds in higher dimensions, and connections between contact geometry and the more familiar Riemannian geometry. In low dimensions the main motivating question is to determine which three-manifolds admit a tight contact structure. Currently quite a bit is known about this question, but very little is known about it for hyperbolic homology spheres. This problem will be studied using a variety of techniques, from convex surfaces, to holomorphic curves and Riemannian geometry. In addition, understanding interactions between various properties a contact structure can have will be studied. While much is known about contact geometry in low dimensions, there is very little known in higher dimensions. The principal investigator will study constructions and properties of high-dimensional contact manifolds. The starting point for this will be the study of isotropic and contact submanifolds of contact manifolds. Such considerations have led to a wealth of information in low-dimensions and it is expected to be similarly fruitful in higher dimensions as well. In the past few years there have been some interesting and subtle connections between contact geometry and Riemannian geometry. The Principal Investigator will explore this further hoping to find contact geometric analogs of classical results relating topology to Riemannian geometry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Contact structures on manifolds are very natural objects, born over two centuries ago, as a natural language for geometric optics, thermodynamics and classical mechanics. Everyday, one encounters contact structures when parallel parking a car, skating, or watching the prismatic play of light in a glass of water. Contact structures have been studied by many mathematicians and seem to touch on diverse areas of mathematics and physics, but only in the last decade or two have they moved into the foreground of mathematics. This is due to the many remarkable breakthroughs in contact topology, resulting in a rich and beautiful theory with many far reaching applications to areas of math and physics. Recently, many breakthroughs in higher dimensional contact geometry has opened the door to new promising lines of research.

Intellectual merit:

In dimension three trying to understand contact structures frequently comes down to understanding various knots within them, in particular in studying Legendrian and transverse knots. In two projects, one with Traynor and Dalton and one with Vertesi, the PI has shown new phenomena with studying Legendrian links (that is unions of disjoint knots) and illuminated how of the topological satellite operation interacts with the classification of Legendrian knots, thus providing more classification results as well as observing interesting interactions of topology and contact geometry.
The PI also studied embeddings of one contact manifold into another. In work with Lekili he showed how to use openbooks to embed contact 3-manifolds into some simple contact 5-manifolds. We also showed there is a unique overtwisted contact structure on S^2 x S^3 into which all contact 3-manifolds embed. This is the simplest topological manifolds where this could happen. In work with Casals he gave the first examples of pairs of isocontact embeddings into the standard contact sphere where are not contact isotopic (though they are formally isotopic). This is the first example of rigidity for contact submanifolds in higher dimensions.
Also in collaboration with Casals, the PI showed that there is a “universal transverse link”. That is a link in the standard contact S^3 such that any contact 3-manifold can be realized as a branched cover over S^3 with branch set this link.
In joint work with his former students Conway and Tosun the PI studied symplectic filling properties of contact structures obtained from contact surgery on Legendrian knots in S^3. They have a complete answer for contact (r) surgery when 01. (The r \leq 0 case was already known.)
The PI and Conway showed that a closed oriented contact manifold is obtained from the standard contact sphere of the same dimension by contact surgeries on isotropic and coisotropic spheres. In addition, they showed that all closed oriented contact manifolds admit symplectic caps.
The PI’s students also made many contributions. His student Kolay proved that any embedding of a 3-manifold in the 5-sphere can be braied in the PL category. His student Min showed classified tight contact structures on the Weeks manifold and in collaboration with a former students classified contact structures on most surgeries on the figure eight knot. This gives the first extensive existence and classification result on an infinite family of hyperbolic manifolds. The PI’s student McCullough found Legendrian knots whose width does not equal their maximum Thurston-Bennequin invariant. This is a surprising property that has not been observed before, and McCullough was able to distill an interesting property that guarantees similar such behavior. The PI’s student Hozoori has provided obstructions to the existence of conformally Anosov Reeb flows on a 3-manifold and showed the 3-sphere does not admit conformally Anosov Reeb flows. In addition, he gave curvature conditions on a metric compatible with a contact structure that implies universal tightness of the contacts structure among other things.

Broader of impacts:

During the course of this grant the PI supervised 7 graduate students and graduated 2 (3 more are close to graduating) and directly mentored 2 postdoctoral fellows (and indirectly mentored several others as well as several junior faculty). He also helped organize and run 6 conferences, giving many junior mathematicians and mathematicians from underrepresented groups an opportunity to advertise their work and initiate collaborations with leaders in the field. He also gave several lectures around the country aimed at introducing a new generation of mathematicians to contact geometry. Most notably, he co-taught a 3 week course at the Park City Math Institute in 2019 aimed at faculty from primarily undergraduate institutions. In addition the PI participated in many formal and informal professional development opportunities for graduate students and young mathematicians. 
In collaboration with Lenny Ng the PI wrote an expository paper on contact homology and Legendrian links, that will hopefully be a useful reference for people wishing to get into the field.
